title: Armed robber had to buy McDonalds cheeseburger before he could flee with takings
text:
Daniel Parra-Braun paid for a cheeseburger before carrying out the heist (Picture: SWNS)

A bungling armed robber was forced to buy a cheeseburger at McDonalds before he could rob the till.

Daniel Parra-Braun burst into the store and placed a note on the counter which read ‘I am armed. Give cash now.’

Workers at the store in Coventry told him they were unable to open the till unless something had been purchased.

The crook then ordered a 99p cheeseburger and even handed over a £5 note before making off with £136 in cash.

Parra-Braun has now been jailed for conducting four robberies in a 12-hour spree in June last year.

Daniel Parra-Braun handed over a note telling staff he was armed (Picture: SWNS)

Warwick Crown Court was told that Parra-Braun marched into the fast food chain on the Gallagher Retail Park in Coventry at 8pm.

As well as the note, he told terrified staff: ‘Give me the money from the till. You’re going to have to, I’m armed.’

After Parra-Braun bought his burger, the server did not hand over any money but the manager gave him £136 from the till.

The robber then fled.

Prosecutor Simon Burch told the court that earlier in the day, Parra-Braun also held up another McDonald’s as well as a bookmakers and a hotel in the city.

He went to William Hill bookmakers and gave a note which read: ‘I am armed. The money from the till please.’

Daniel Parra-Braun handed over a £5 note to pay for his 99p cheeseburger before fleeing with the takings from the till (Picture: SWNS)

Mr Burch said: ‘Addressing a member of staff by her first name, with his hand in his pocket to feign to have a weapon, he told her: “I don’t want to whack it out, I just want the money”.’

He left with £170 in cash but the staff recognised Parra-Braun as a regular who lived in a flat over the road.

Parra-Braun then held up the McDonald’s before heading to the Premier Inn in the city centre where he again handed over a note to the receptionist which read: ‘Till’.

But he was forced to flee empty-handed after being informed the hotel had already taken the cash to the bank.

Twenty minutes later he targeted a city centre McDonalds where he handed a staff member a note with ‘armed’ and ‘money’ written on it.

No cash was handed over and the manager called the police and Parra-Braun was arrested nearby.

The court heard that no weapon was found.

Parra-Braun held up two McDonalds restaurants in Coventry as well as a hotel and bookmakers (Picture: SWNS)

Parra-Braun has 11 convictions for offences including theft and he was jailed for five years.

Judge Peter Cooke told him: ‘I accept that this bizarre few hours in your life was the product of something of a psychiatric collapse you had suffered.

‘Your behaviour has that peculiar flavour to it and was not just about obtaining money.

‘There is no suggestion you produced or had a weapon, but the people on the other end of the threats were not to know that.’

In mitigation, Ian Windridge said Parra-Braun, of Coventry, struggled with his mental health, adding: ‘He wasn’t in need of money.

‘It was a cry for help, but not a substantial one.’
